subject: FruDevice: Add DDR5 format support
commitMessage:
FruDevice: Add DDR5 format support

This commit implements the parser of DDR5 SPD.

Tested:
Ran unittests locally and passed.

Signed-off-by: Michael Shen <gpgpgp@google.com>
Change-Id: I8885e98247828a4b4e7080a0bc133c7a2f625e93

Abandoned

Content of this CL is merged into https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435
a single sentence is rarely enough detail, and certainly not enough for adding a major feature like this.  Please go a little deeper into "why" this change is useful in your commit message please.

Thanks for all the comments.
As you said, it's difficult to verify this patchset unless the entire series are avaliable.
So I will push the rest of patchset first then come back to solve the defect here.
I think this series can be completed within 2 more patches.
The endianness needs to be represented in the class, not just in a comment.
Done, change to `boost::endian::little_xxxxx` as you suggested.
Why not uint16_t?
Done
Similar to how we pull the PCIe manufacturer ID tables, is this going to pull the JEDEC manufacturer tables?
Done. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435/13/include/manufacturer_id_table.hpp

Relying on packed encodings is error prone and in general is no prefered in openbmc, because it generally relies on explicit handling of endian values (through something like boost::endian::little_int32_buf_t for example)

Considering that a lot of these fields aren't in a representation we'd want in the bmc anyway (partNumber should ideally be std::string, or std::string_view) I suspect we want to break this class up into a method that parses into a structure that the BMC can operate on.
I removed the `__attribute__((packed))` and changed all the none 1-byte variable into boost::endian::little_xxxxxxx
These things should be under if(debug) flags, otherwise they will print for a large number of frus that look like jedec, but aren't.
Done
Please use the appropiate types for these things such that static casts aren't required.
nit, check against < 0 please in case this function decides to return other negative values in the future.
I change it to optional.
Changed to std::optional.
per our coding standard, new and delete shouldn't be used anymore.  make_unique should be prefered in these cases.

You're passing a non-owning span to a class that's being returned in a unique_ptr.  This pattern can VERY easily lead to lifetime issues.  I suspect that the interfaces need to be reworked to convey ownership of the buffer (probably handing ownership to the DDR5SPD class)

please use array for values known at compile time.

Also, please cite the source for these values.
Done
Please use a real class for this.
Done

magic number?  This is somewhat pointing to what I pointed out earlier about using pragma(packed) to decode buffers being error prone.  Almost all places where this code calls into spd_-> aren't range checked, and given that the buffer interfaces only enfoce a minimum size of 3, means that it would be pretty easy to write a buffer that would make this code seg fault.
Fixed. Now the constructor will do all the size check instead of check in the each method.
Considering that a part could have negative values in this, do we want a better return type here?

It returns string now. I put the MFRIDJEP106 in the code.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435/13/include/manufacturer_id_table.hpp
Considering we have enums for other things, do we need an enum class for these?  (could be declared in this class if you wanted).

In the latest revision I make this function private since it's only used for calculate dimm size.
Hence I don't think we need a enum class for this.
Why are we masking these here?  This seems like we should be checking against negative values?
Obsoleted. Now we directly return manufacturer's name.

I mentioned on an earlier patch, but these should be:

Returning a time_point
need range checks to ensure that the values are sane (ie, not negative or overflowing).

Change the type to `std::chrono::time_point<std::chrono::system_clock>`

> need range checks to ensure that the values are sane (ie, not negative or overflowing).

negative number is not possible. I can only check if week is overflowing (>53)
prefer to use std::string here, considering that surely this has some rule about length that we should be enforcing here.  If these are truly fixed length, then we should be returning by std::array.
Done

This has the potential to put null terminators (zeros) in the result, which is definitely now what you intended.

ie, an empty part number should return "", not "\x00\x00\x00..."

I dont know what the jedec spec requires for termination characters, but it should be handled here.

Cite from `JC-45-2260.01`
```
Bytes 521~550 (0x209~0x226): Module Part Number
The manufacturer’s part number shall be included and is written in ASCII format within these
bytes. Unused digits are coded as ASCII blanks (0x20).
```

> This has the potential to put null terminators (zeros) in the result, which is definitely now what you intended.

From the spec it doesn't/can't contain null (0x00)

> ie, an empty part number should return "", not "\x00\x00\x00..."

In this case the content should be "0x20, 0x20, 0x20...."

----------------------------------------------------------------

I remembered you mentioned that we should make those functions easy to use.
So in the latest revision I check the content of partNumber and trim all the illegal character (non-printable and space) out.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435/13/src/spd.cpp#393
the left shift logic looks duplicated between the branches, as is a bunch of the math (kprimaryBusWidthPerChannel/kWidth for example) can it be deduplicated?
Fixed.
Don't duplicate this static cast, make another variable. for it.
Done
This API should be returning an enum that's more useful.  You've documented the things in a comment below, it just needs to be turned into an enum class.
Done. Now it return Dimm::Ecc that defined in <xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Dimm/server.hpp>

I restruct the code to remove the inheritance.
So the content of this CL merges into https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435, and this will be abandoned.

While I fixed all the issues that reviewer mentioned in this CL.
Please directly review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435 instead of this.

Thanks!
